New Records: India recorded their eighth consecutive win against Pakistan at an ODI World Cup.
Rohit Sharma made an elegant, sadistic 86 from 63 balls, with six sixes.
Rohit Sharma has scored his eighth century in the last 15 World Cup innings.
India need 96 to win and are romping to victory, and we haven’t yet had 50 overs in the match.
India have played with intimidating authority and it’s hard to see anyone beating them, although many of us thought the same in 2019.
Key Match Events: India thrashed Pakistan by seven wickets with almost 20 overs to spare.
Rohit Sharma was inspired with both brain and bat, making an elegant, sadistic 86 from 63 balls, with six sixes.
Pakistan collapsed miserably from 155/2 to 191 all out.
India's bowlers set the game up for them, restricting Pakistan to 190 was a great effort.
Rohit Sharma humoured Pakistan's bowler for a few deliveries and then flicked lazily over midwicket for six.
Rohit Sharma made the most languid statement of intent, flicking Afrdi’s first ball up and over the leg side for four.
Shubman Gill, back in the side after Dengue fever, times his first ball past extra cover for four more.

India’s captain Rohit Sharma kept making things happen with his bowling changes, showing some inspired faith in Siraj and Hardik Pandya, getting two wickets from all five of his main bowlers, bringing Bumrah back at just the right moment, and calling for some clever reviews.
Rohit Sharma decides to review when Haris Rauf LBW ball seems to be sliding down leg, and many other people, to be hitting! And Pakistan’s calamity is complete, with seven overs unused.
Pre-Game Insights: India win the toss and decide to bowl first.
India captain Rohit Sharma speaks: The bowlers set the game up for us. Restricting them to 190 was a great effort – at one stage we were looking at 270/280.
Pakistan captain Babar Azam speaks: We started well, then suddenly we collapsed in the middle overs. It’s not good. We were aiming for 280/290 but that collapse cost us.
Post-Match Reflections: India captain Rohit Sharma: The bowlers set the game up for us. Restricting them to 190 was a great effort – at one stage we were looking at 270/280.
Pakistan captain Babar Azam: We started well, then suddenly we collapsed in the middle overs. It’s not good. We were aiming for 280/290 but that collapse cost us.
Player of the match is Jasprit Bumrah: It felt good. We try to analyse the wicket as soon as possible; we realised it was on the slower side and that a hard length would make run-scoring difficult.
Miscellaneous Highlights: India need 96 to win and are romping to victory, and we haven’t yet had 50 overs in the match.
India have played with intimidating authority and it’s hard to see anyone beating them, although many of us thought the same in 2019.
The score is India 7-0 Pakistan at ODI World Cups, and this is the most emphatic win of the lot.
The player of the match at this stage is Rohit Sharma, by a mile.
This will surely go down as one of the all-time great capitulations.

India's captain Rohit Sharma kept making things happen with his bowling changes, showing some inspired faith in Siraj and Hardik Pandya, getting two wickets from all five of his main bowlers, bringing Bumrah back at just the right moment, and calling for some clever reviews.
Others: Pakistan's collapse was described as a calamity, with seven overs unused.

Rohit Sharma has been slightly skittish tonight and almost offers Hasan Ali a return catch with an uppish drive.
